Go to the end to download the full example code.

Electrode Creation

Before creating any electrodes, we need to familiarize ourselves with a few concepts. First- whenever you initialize a system, you need to pick nr, nz, axial_size and radial_size. nr is the grid resolution in the r-dimension, and nz is the same for the z-dimension. Axial_size is the total length of the domain in meters in the z-dimension, and radial_size is the same for the r-dimension.

This means the grid resolution in the z-dimension is axial_size/nz, and in the r-dimension is radial_size/nr. You should, if using nonstandard values for these, ensure you’re aware of these so you can properly convert from grid units to meters.

You can initialize a cylindrical electrode with -5000V focus voltage and 10keV energy per electron as follows:

13 import numpy as np
14 from picht import IonOpticsSystem, ElectrodeConfig
15 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
16
17 #Specifies the grid size, resolution, and domain
18 system = IonOpticsSystem(nr=100, nz=600, axial_size=0.6, radial_size = 0.1)
19
20 #Configures electrode parameterization
21 electrode = ElectrodeConfig(
22     start=30,
23     width=5,
24     ap_start=40,
25     ap_width=20,
26     outer_diameter = 50,
27     voltage=-5000
28 )
29
30 system.add_electrode(electrode)
31
32 #FDM field solving stage
33 potential = system.solve_fields()
34
35 #Beam parameterization
36 trajectories = system.simulate_beam(
37     energy_eV= 10000,
38     start_z=0,
39     r_range=(0.0499925, 0.0500075),
40     angle_range=(0, 0),
41     num_particles=6,
42     simulation_time=2e-9
43 )
44
45 #Visualization control
46 figure = system.visualize_system(
47     trajectories=trajectories)
48
49 plt.show()

Total running time of the script: (0 minutes 3.203 seconds)

Download Python source code: example_cylindrical_lens.py
